answers.answer: Hi, THese labs posted are within normal range. So from that, it does not sound like hypothyroidism.THere are any number of factors that need to be verified and ruled out.Did they run the thyroid antibody tests and the free t3?Are you blood sugars running in range? Have you changed manufactors of your insulin?Have you had your adrenal glands tested?Did he offer to run any further tests to verify that this is being caused by the diabetes? I know from experience, that most drs, just like to decide instead of verify.That really gets my goat, because if all they are going to do is make an educated guess, I can just stay home, get on medhelp and get my friends opinion. (did not mean to get on my soapbox)This is just ssome suggestions to get you started. I am sure someone else will come along with some other good suggestions. In the meantime, TRY,(difficult I know from experience) to relax and not stress to much as that does damage to your body.

As Peg said TSH is "normal" but the T4 is useless to help decided if you have a possible problem converting FT4 into FT3.FT3 (Free T3) is essential is maintain metobolism. If you are suffering from weight gain - you could be having issies with FT3.  You other symptoms indicate this also could be an issue,Your doctor is running basic thyroid testing on you and you do not want that. Request the Free's ran and not the standard T testing.Additonally adding a TPO antibody test - a cortisol test would be good too.

Thanks for the comments.  I did have a cortisol run and it was normal.  I'm frustrated because the doctors just don't seem to see past my diabetes.  I feel like they should have tested for these things long ago.What is a tpo anitbody test?

It tests for antibodies to your thyroid, to determine if your thyroid is attacking itself. Google hashimoto's disease.In regards to your dr, I would look for another one, because as you put it, he can't look past the diabetes. It sounds like he has made his mind up and is not open to any other diagnosis or treatments.Reread what I said about the drs. It is true, as you have experienced it first hand.

Thanks.   I am going to a see a NP at a new endo's office next week.  I'm going to try to relax until then.  It just gets to a point where you don't want to repeat all this stuff to one more medical professional who most likely will dismiss you anyway.I also have family history of Pituitary disorders and other autoimmune disorders like celiac disease.  None of these things have been tested either, other than the anti body test for celiac.Sorry to vent.  I think I let this go to long.  I'm glad I found some support here.  Thanks.

question: I NEED HELP!  I am so frustrated with my doctors.  Over the last 7 months I have gained 28 pounds and have almost all other symptoms of hypothryoidism.  I finally got fed up last week with trying to get through to my doctors and had my husband come to my appointment.  My family doctor agreed to put me on synthroid (50mg) to "see what happens".My last several labs have shown my TSH between .84-1.8 (.3-5.0 lab limits) and but my T4 free has been .7-.8 (.7-2.0 lab limits).  Can this still be hypothyroidism?My endo does not think I should be take synthroid and wants me to wait and see.  UGGGHHH!!!  I'm just so sick of this.  I don't feel well at all.I was diagnosed with Type 1 diabetes 3.5 years ago at age 27 and am on an insulin pump.  My endo and family doc like to explain away all my symptoms to my diabetes.  However, the weight gain, headaches, fatigue, and other symptoms have really only been an issue the last 7 months.Thanks for listening to my story.  Any help or encouragement welcomed.
title: Help! Doctors have me so confused.
